heritage-monuments.title: Heritage Monuments
heritage-monuments.description: Test your knowledge about India's magnificent monuments and architectural marvels

questions.question: Which monument is known as the 'Symbol of Love'?
questions.explanation: The Taj Mahal in Agra is famously known as the 'Symbol of Love', built by Shah Jahan for his wife Mumtaz Mahal.

questions.question: In which city is the Red Fort (Lal Qila) located?
questions.explanation: The Red Fort is located in Old Delhi, New Delhi, and served as the main residence of the Mughal emperors.

questions.question: Which fort is known as the 'Golden Fort'?
questions.explanation: Jaisalmer Fort is known as the 'Golden Fort' due to its golden sandstone construction that glows like gold in sunlight.

questions.question: The Khajuraho temples are famous for their:
questions.explanation: The Khajuraho temples are renowned for their intricate erotic sculptures and are a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

questions.question: Which monument houses the tomb of Akbar?
questions.explanation: Sikandra in Agra houses the tomb of the Mughal Emperor Akbar the Great.

questions.question: The Gateway of India was built to commemorate the visit of which British monarchs?
options: King George V and Queen Mary
questions.explanation: The Gateway of India was built to commemorate the visit of King George V and Queen Mary to Mumbai in 1911.

questions.question: Which temple is carved entirely out of a single rock?
questions.explanation: The Kailasa Temple at Ellora is the world's largest monolithic structure, carved entirely from a single rock.

questions.question: The Lotus Temple in Delhi belongs to which faith?
questions.explanation: The Lotus Temple is a Baháʼí House of Worship, known for its distinctive lotus flower-like design.

questions.question: Which is the tallest brick minaret in the world?
questions.explanation: Qutub Minar in Delhi is the tallest brick minaret in the world, standing at 72.5 meters.

questions.question: The Ajanta Caves are primarily famous for:
questions.explanation: The Ajanta Caves are renowned for their ancient Buddhist paintings and rock-cut sculptures dating from 2nd century BCE.

questions.question: Which monument is known as the 'Black Pagoda'?
questions.explanation: The Sun Temple at Konark is known as the 'Black Pagoda' due to its dark appearance from the sea.

questions.question: Hampi was the capital of which ancient empire?
questions.explanation: Hampi was the capital of the Vijayanagara Empire and is now a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

festivals.title: Indian Festivals
festivals.description: Explore the vibrant world of Indian festivals and celebrations

questions.question: During which festival do people celebrate the victory of light over darkness?
questions.explanation: Diwali, the Festival of Lights, celebrates the victory of light over darkness and good over evil.

questions.question: Holi is primarily celebrated to mark the arrival of which season?
questions.explanation: Holi marks the arrival of spring and is celebrated with colors to welcome the new season.

questions.question: Which festival is known as the 'Festival of Harvest' in South India?
questions.explanation: Pongal is the harvest festival celebrated in Tamil Nadu to thank the Sun God for a good harvest.

questions.question: Ganesh Chaturthi celebrates the birth of which deity?
questions.explanation: Ganesh Chaturthi celebrates the birth of Lord Ganesha, the elephant-headed deity and remover of obstacles.

questions.question: Which festival involves the worship of the Moon?
questions.explanation: Karva Chauth involves married women fasting and worshipping the Moon for their husband's long life.

questions.question: Onam is the harvest festival of which Indian state?
questions.explanation: Onam is the harvest festival of Kerala, celebrating the return of the legendary King Mahabali.

questions.question: Which festival commemorates the victory of Lord Rama over Ravana?
questions.explanation: Dussehra commemorates the victory of Lord Rama over the demon king Ravana, symbolizing good over evil.

questions.question: Baisakhi is primarily celebrated in which region of India?
questions.explanation: Baisakhi is primarily celebrated in Punjab and marks the harvest season and the formation of the Khalsa.

questions.question: Which festival is celebrated by flying kites?
questions.explanation: Makar Sankranti is celebrated by flying colorful kites, especially in Gujarat and other parts of India.

questions.question: Chhath Puja is dedicated to which celestial body?
questions.explanation: Chhath Puja is dedicated to the Sun God (Surya) and is mainly celebrated in Bihar and eastern Uttar Pradesh.

questions.question: Which festival marks the beginning of the Hindu New Year in many regions?
questions.explanation: Gudi Padwa marks the beginning of the Hindu New Year and spring season in Maharashtra and other regions.

questions.question: Durga Puja is most prominently celebrated in which Indian state?
questions.explanation: Durga Puja is most prominently celebrated in West Bengal, honoring Goddess Durga's victory over evil.

classical-arts.title: Classical Arts
classical-arts.description: Challenge yourself on traditional dances, music, and art forms

questions.question: Which classical dance form originated in Tamil Nadu?
questions.explanation: Bharatanatyam originated in Tamil Nadu and is one of the oldest classical dance forms of India.

questions.question: Kathak dance form originated in which region of India?
questions.explanation: Kathak originated in North India, particularly in the states of Uttar Pradesh and Rajasthan.

questions.question: Which stringed instrument is known as the 'King of Instruments' in Indian classical music?
questions.explanation: The Sitar is often called the 'King of Instruments' in Hindustani classical music.

questions.question: Odissi dance originated in which Indian state?
questions.explanation: Odissi dance originated in Odisha and is characterized by its graceful movements and expressions.

questions.question: Which percussion instrument is most commonly used in South Indian classical music?
questions.explanation: Mridangam is the primary percussion instrument used in Carnatic (South Indian) classical music.

questions.question: Kuchipudi dance form belongs to which Indian state?
questions.explanation: Kuchipudi is a classical dance form that originated in Andhra Pradesh, named after the village Kuchipudi.

questions.question: Which raga is traditionally performed in the early morning?
questions.explanation: Raga Bhairav is traditionally performed in the early morning and is considered very sacred.

questions.question: Mohiniyattam dance form originated in which state?
questions.explanation: Mohiniyattam is a classical dance form that originated in Kerala, performed by women.

questions.question: Which instrument is known as the 'Divine Instrument' in Indian classical music?
questions.explanation: The Veena is often referred to as the 'Divine Instrument' and is considered the mother of all stringed instruments.

questions.question: Sattriya dance is associated with which Indian state?
questions.explanation: Sattriya is a classical dance form from Assam, traditionally performed in monasteries.

questions.question: Which classical music tradition uses the term 'Alapana'?
questions.explanation: Alapana is a form of musical improvisation in Carnatic (South Indian) classical music.

questions.question: The tabla consists of how many drums?
questions.explanation: The tabla consists of two drums: the smaller 'tabla' or 'dayan' and the larger 'baya'.

ancient-history.title: Ancient History
ancient-history.description: Journey through India's ancient civilizations and historical events

questions.question: The Indus Valley Civilization flourished around which river?
questions.explanation: The Indus Valley Civilization flourished around the Indus River, covering parts of modern-day Pakistan and northwest India.

questions.question: Who was the founder of the Mauryan Empire?
questions.explanation: Chandragupta Maurya founded the Mauryan Empire around 321 BCE with the help of Chanakya.

questions.question: Which ancient university was located in Bihar?
questions.explanation: Nalanda University was an ancient center of learning located in Bihar, attracting students from across Asia.

questions.question: The Gupta period is known as the:
questions.explanation: The Gupta period (320-550 CE) is known as the Golden Age of India due to achievements in art, science, and literature.

questions.question: Which emperor is known for spreading Buddhism?
questions.explanation: Emperor Ashoka is famous for spreading Buddhism across and beyond India after the Kalinga War.

questions.question: The ancient text 'Arthashastra' was written by:
questions.explanation: Arthashastra, a treatise on statecraft and economics, was written by Chanakya (Kautilya).

questions.question: Which dynasty built the famous temples at Khajuraho?
questions.explanation: The Chandela dynasty built the famous temples at Khajuraho between 950 and 1050 CE.

questions.question: The Battle of Kalinga was fought by which emperor?
questions.explanation: The Battle of Kalinga was fought by Emperor Ashoka, which led to his conversion to Buddhism.

questions.question: Which ancient Indian mathematician invented the concept of zero?
questions.explanation: Brahmagupta was the first to give rules for computing with zero and negative numbers.

questions.question: The Ajanta Caves were built during which period?
questions.explanation: The Ajanta Caves were built over several centuries, spanning the Mauryan, Satavahana, and Gupta periods.

questions.question: Who wrote the epic Mahabharata?
questions.explanation: The Mahabharata is traditionally attributed to sage Vyasa (Ved Vyasa).

questions.question: The Chola dynasty was famous for their expertise in:
questions.explanation: The Cholas were renowned for their temple architecture, powerful navy, and extensive trade networks.

regional-culture.title: Regional Culture
regional-culture.description: Discover the diverse cultural traditions across Indian states

questions.question: Which state is famous for its backwaters?
questions.explanation: Kerala is famous for its scenic backwaters, especially in Alleppey and Kumarakoram.

questions.question: Bihu is the traditional festival of which state?
questions.explanation: Bihu is the traditional New Year festival of Assam, celebrated three times a year.

questions.question: Which state is known as the 'Land of Five Rivers'?
questions.explanation: Punjab is known as the 'Land of Five Rivers' - Sutlej, Beas, Ravi, Chenab, and Jhelum.

questions.question: Pongal is primarily celebrated in which state?
questions.explanation: Pongal is the harvest festival primarily celebrated in Tamil Nadu.

questions.question: Which state is famous for its tea gardens?
questions.explanation: Assam is world-famous for its tea gardens and produces about half of India's tea.

questions.question: Giddha is a folk dance from which state?
questions.explanation: Giddha is a traditional folk dance performed by women in Punjab.

questions.question: Which state is known for its handloom silk sarees called 'Kanjeevaram'?
questions.explanation: Kanjeevaram sarees are world-famous silk sarees from Kanchipuram in Tamil Nadu.

questions.question: Hornbill Festival is celebrated in which northeastern state?
questions.explanation: The Hornbill Festival is celebrated in Nagaland and showcases the rich cultural heritage of Naga tribes.

questions.question: Which state is famous for its Blue Pottery?
questions.explanation: Rajasthan, particularly Jaipur, is famous for its beautiful Blue Pottery craft.

questions.question: Lavani is a traditional dance form of which state?
questions.explanation: Lavani is a traditional dance form of Maharashtra, known for its powerful rhythm and quick tempo.

questions.question: Which state is known as 'God's Own Country'?
questions.explanation: Kerala is popularly known as 'God's Own Country' due to its natural beauty and cultural richness.

questions.question: Phulkari embroidery is traditional to which region?
questions.explanation: Phulkari is a traditional embroidery technique from Punjab, literally meaning 'flower work'.

hidden-gems.title: Hidden Gems
hidden-gems.description: Explore lesser-known heritage sites and cultural treasures

questions.question: Mawlynnong village in Meghalaya is famous for being:
questions.explanation: Mawlynnong in Meghalaya is known as 'Asia's Cleanest Village' and is famous for its living root bridges.

questions.question: The Magnetic Hill is located in which union territory?
questions.explanation: Magnetic Hill is located in Ladakh, where vehicles appear to move uphill on their own due to an optical illusion.

questions.question: Bhangarh Fort, known for being haunted, is located in which state?
questions.explanation: Bhangarh Fort is located in Rajasthan and is famous for being one of India's most haunted places.

questions.question: The living root bridges are naturally found in which state?
questions.explanation: Living root bridges are naturally occurring bridges in Meghalaya, created by training rubber tree roots.

questions.question: Loktak Lake with floating islands is located in which state?
questions.explanation: Loktak Lake in Manipur is famous for its floating islands called 'phumdis'.

questions.question: The Chitrakote Falls, known as India's Niagara, is in which state?
questions.explanation: Chitrakote Falls in Chhattisgarh is often called the 'Niagara of India' due to its horseshoe shape.

questions.question: Dzukou Valley, famous for its flowers, is located between which two states?
questions.explanation: Dzukou Valley lies on the border of Nagaland and Manipur, famous for its seasonal flowers.

questions.question: The Chandrashila Peak is famous for which temple?
questions.explanation: Chandrashila Peak in Uttarakhand is famous for the Tungnath Temple, the highest Shiva temple.

questions.question: Marble Rocks (Bhedaghat) is located on which river?
questions.explanation: The Marble Rocks at Bhedaghat in Madhya Pradesh are located on the Narmada River.

questions.question: The Rann of Kutch is famous for which natural phenomenon?
questions.explanation: The Rann of Kutch is famous for being a vast salt desert that transforms during the monsoon.

questions.question: Sandakphu, the highest peak of West Bengal, offers views of which mountain range?
questions.explanation: Sandakphu offers panoramic views of the Himalayan range including Everest and Kanchenjunga.

questions.question: The Unakoti sculptures are located in which northeastern state?
questions.explanation: Unakoti in Tripura features ancient rock-cut sculptures and carvings dating back to the 7th-9th centuries.
